But this move is very unusual, and for good reason. In an open position like this, white can't afford to waste moves like this.

So I strike out in the centre. My d pawn is backward on a semi-open file, and can potentially be attacked by his rooks and queen along the d semi-open d file. But in return black gains a measure of central control.
I don't think this is the best square to put the knight.
So I carry on with my development

So this is his plan. The e pawn is protected by his Ng3 so he can play Nc3-d5 and he can also play Bc1-e3 without fear of me playing Nf6-g4 in reply. The downside is that he has wasted so many moves with his knight now at g3. Black is ahead in development.
So I continue to develop
He takes control of the d5 square.
So I prepare to hit his bishop
He prepares a retreat square
I ht the bishop
He retreats
I contest the a2-g8 diagonal
He throws the knight in. Now I have to be careful. I want to play Nc6-a5-c4, but Na5 immediately loses to Be6-b6, which is one reason for my next move, to cover the b6 square again
